content.question: Which of the following best describes how amino acids affect the tertiary structure of a protein?

choices.label: The number of amino acids determines the tertiary structure of the protein.

The interactions of the different <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-groups with other <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-groups and with their environment determine the tertiary structure of the protein.

The <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-group of the last amino acid that is added to a growing polypeptide chain determines the next amino acid that is added to the chain.
The sequence of the amino acids in the polypeptide chain determines the proteinâ€™s primary structure but has no effect on its tertiary structure.

content.answer: The interactions of the different <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-groups with other <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-groups and with their environment determine the tertiary structure of the protein.
